course.subject: BIEN
course.name: Data Science for Molecular Engineering
course.description: Mathematical methods for data science; Data processing and presentation; Supervised learning, including nearest neighbor methods, linear and nonlinear regression; Introduction to deep learning and neural networks.
course.prerequisites: BIEN 2310 OR CENG 2310
course.exclusions: LIFS 3150, MATH 2411

reviews.author: SATB
reviews.comment_content:
Part 0. Introduction
Week 1 Real-world applications of data science in physical, chemical and life
sciences
Part 1. Math Methods for Data Science
Week 2 Basic concepts in linear algebra, calculus and numerical optimization
Week 3 Review of statistics and probability
Part 2. Data Processing
Week 4 Introduction to Python and Pandas for Processing Tabulated Data
Week 5 Cheminformatics toolboxes – the example of RDKit
Week 6 Results visualization – molecules, chemical reactions, trees, graphs
Part 4. Supervised Learning
Week 7 Introduction to common supervised learning problems in molecular
engineering
Week 8 Linear regression - molecular property predictions and feature importance
Week 9 Molecular feature engineering and nonlinear regression
Week 10 Introduction to deep learning and neural networks
Part 5. Miscellaneous Topics
Week 11 Introduction to unsupervised learning and reinforcement learning
Week 12 Data collection and design of experiments in molecular engineering
Week 13 Course project presentation
reviews.comment_teaching:
2 1.5-hour lectures per week, Prof Gao usually used the first lecture in a week to go through the lecture slides, and then the second lecture will be an interactive coding session.

I did not find the teaching particularly interesting. I think it is more important that we read enough documentation about the modules we are using for the coding part. Be sure to be fluent in the most common functions in modules like sci-kit learn, RDKit, etc.
reviews.comment_workload:
Very light, only 2 pieces of homework, both about coding. Although the questions may be long, you can always use Prof's codes in class as a template.

1 individual course project, we must work on something related to data science, preferably (but not limited to) the field of molecular engineering. The easiest way is to apply the codes demonstrated in class in a different context, since the same algorithm can be applied in many scenarios.

The final exam is all about coding and manipulating all the functions and algorithms that were taught in class. It should not be difficult if you understand the codes thoroughly. Be sure to read carefully about the questions, don't miss out on any small detail!
